awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Subsistence Adaptation in a High Altitude Environment
awd_abstract_narration:
Zhengwei Zhang and Dr. Xinyi Liu, of the Washington University in St. Louis, along with colleagues will conduct research to explore the animal-based subsistence strategies in a high altitude extreme environment. Understanding of the development of high-altitude adaptations in has been enriched by recent anthropological investigations. Such studies have revealed specific challenges regarding strategies for securing a reliable food supply in different seasons. The goal of this research is to increase understanding of how to achieve long-term resilience in the context of concerns regarding food security and more frequent extreme climate events. Archaeology is well placed to provide meaningful insights on resilience because it provides information on people’s behaviors over a long time span. This research will promote understanding of the past, as well as the present by documenting invaluable animal resources and resilient strategies in harsh areas, where biodiversity is threatened. Educational and outreach activities will deepen broad scale academic cooperation, as well as facilitate the development of open academic environments. 

By focusing on animal resources that people used at high altitudes, this research explores the ways that societies were able to be more resilient to periodic stresses and to survive despite the inhospitable and unpredictable environment. The researchers will conduct comprehensive study of prehistoric animal remains from one of the world’s most inhospitable areas. The questions of how farming and hunting settlers managed to live year-round in this high altitude region remain largely unanswered and have been obscured by the scarcity of zooarchaeological studies conducted to date. The researchers will combine systematic zooarchaeological and stable isotopes analyses, and regional ethnographical surveys. This research will reveal animal-based subsistence strategies of pastoral groups and investigate at high resolution how they managed livestock and utilized local natural landscapes. This research has the potential to shed light on human communities’ resilience in extreme environments worldwide.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Recent archaeological investigations have enriched our understanding of human adaptations to high-elevation environments worldwide. The Tibetan Plateau is one of the most challenging environments for humanity, facing high-altitude and hypoxia conditions. By at least 3500 BP, the establishment of multi-resource pastoralism incorporating livestock management and cereal cultivations had enabled the expansion of settlements on the plateau. How early communities managed their livestock to cope with the challenging environments remains unanswered. By engaging with recent discoveries in the southern Tibetan Plateau at the site of Bangga (3000-2000 cal. BP), this research addresses the missing piece of the story. We employed a combined zooarchaeological and isotopic approach to answering two questions: 1) How might environmental conditions have threatened the survival of early herders at the high elevations? 2) How early Tibetan pastoralists managed their livestock to cope with environmental pressures?

 

Our results offer an original contribution in two principal respects regarding the challenge faced by early herders at c. 4000 m a.s.l. and their solutions. We used dental eruption and wear to reconstruct sheep mortality profiles from Bangga. The mortality profiles revealed that more than 60% of the sheep died within the first year. Simulations based on ethnographic data from Tibet suggested the pattern may be the product of high natural lamb death rates in high-risk environments, challenging the conventional interpretation of culling in the context of milk management. This finding indicates that high juvenile mortality threatened ancient sheepherders. To enable insights into herding practices at such a condition, we conducted sequential isotope analyses of archaeological enamel bioapatite of sheep and goats from Bangga. The isotopic results suggested that some sheep and goats were provisioned with groundwater and fodder composed of agricultural products year around. Other animals may have been taken to graze in saline or marsh environments during the summer. These results provide fresh insight into the prehistoric agropastoralism in high-altitude Tibet, where decreased seasonal mobility corresponding to increased provisioning input differs from the extensive approach previously documented at lower altitudes.
